subject: Ethics
title: Sustainability as Moral Imperative
description: A quick win: understand Sustainability as Moral Imperative.

hook.text: We use 1.7 Earths' worth of resources every year. Last we checked, we only have one.

buildup.text: Sustainability means meeting today's needs without stealing from future generations' ability to meet theirs.

discovery.text: The 1987 Brundtland Report made this definition famous, linking development and environmental protection.

twist.text: But 'sustainable growth' on a finite planet is a contradiction. True sustainability may require consuming less.

climax.text: Sustainability isn't a lifestyle brand. It's a moral duty to leave behind a planet that still works.

punchline.text: One planet. No backup. That's the whole argument.

quiz.question: What is the Brundtland Report's definition of sustainability?
options: Meeting present needs without compromising future generations' ability to meet theirs
Using resources as fast as possible to maximize economic growth
Eliminating all industrial activity to protect the environment
